Fields.DialogueText: Captain! Captain, they need you out on deck right now!
What's going on? Are we under attack?
Ah... Sort of, Captain. Lady Achilles apparently had an... "incident" with another Belle whose squadron has just departed. She hasn't hurt anyone yet, but...
Fine, I'll handle it. Clear the deck! Now!
Aye, sir. Right away, sir.
I swear I'm going to feed her her own guts! I shall not stand for this!
Achilles, calm down. You're scaring the children, and no one likes to see their mum as an angry drunk.
I am neither a mother nor a drunk! Nor are the sailors children.
You're certainly angry, though. What's wrong?
One of the Japanese Belles had the gall to call me arrogant. Me! Then she said I'm an insult to my people's warrior legacy!
Captain, surely there must be rules in the treaty allowing INPF ships to duel each other!

Fields.MenuText: I really, really don't think there are.
An insult to your warrior heritage is certainly going a bit too far.
So... why do you care what she says?

Fields.DialogueText: There should be!
Not the arrogance, though? I'll remember that slight as well.
Because. Because. Well. I have to respect her on some level, damn it! Her reputation's sterling, and she's hell in a fight.
Does this rival at least have a Belle? Unlike Ajax?
You're never going to let that go, are you?
Only when it stops being funny.
*ALARM*
Grr... My javelins are restless. Be thankful I have those Morganas to practice on.
@BATTLE
So what else did you talk to this IJN Belle about? It had to be more than just what you've told me. Either something's wrong with your boilers or you're still fuming.
We... had a bit of a debate before she insulted me.
I maintain that victory is a warrior's greatest virtue. She believes it is discipline, and that a disciplined foe can and should be respected in defeat.
It's so strange, Captain. I think many of her own comrades of the Imperial Japanese Navy would also find it odd.
Regardless of the accuracy of her opinion, it certainly seems to have gotten under your skin.
What do you think, Captain? Surely you have an opinion on this.

Fields.MenuText: Honor is a component of duty. Discipline is part of your honor. The more disciplined and steadfast you are, the less likely you are to face defeat to start with.
Victory is the only thing worth discussing in the end. It is the goal we must strive for.
As an officer, I think the most important thing I can do is accomplish my objectives with minimal bloodshed.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, this... is a fair point. It sounds more fair coming from you than from her.
Yes, one must keep one's eyes on the prize, as I hear the Americans put it.
...You make a fair point Captain, I don't think anyone can argue with that without being some sort of monster.
I have something to think on now. I suppose I'll go and...
*ALARM*
...send some sea witches back to Tartarus!
I swear it's like they know I'm trying to get something done.
@BATTLE
Captain, a moment of your time?
I always have time for you, Achilles.
I know. I wasn't asking - I was just being polite.
Indeed. What's on your mind?
The Battle of Thermopylae: victory or defeat?
Well, considering King Leonidas, his three hundred Spartans, and some seven hundred of their Greek allies got slaughtered to a man...
I'm serious, Captain. You be serious too.

Fields.MenuText: A defeat, unquestionably, but they knew that going into it.
Victory. The Greeks held up the Persians long enough to finish the job at Salamis and Plataea.
I don't think it matters. Honor and valour are found in conduct, not victory or defeat.

Fields.DialogueText: They did. I can't help but wonder if that changed things. Taking an army of thousands against a horde of a million or more...
An excellent point. Victory had a price. Leonidas, his three hundred, and the Greek allies under his command were that price.
And they earned every bit of it. The story of Thermopylae is the story of the warrior ideal.
Your counsel is wise indeed. I knew I chose well when I selected you!
"Go and tell the Spartans, stranger passing by, that here obedient to their laws we lie." The epitaph of the Spartans by the historian Simonides.
Yes... indeed.
You have an odd look on your face.
I... need to take some moments alone, I am... considering your words, and reconsidering that Japanese Belle's words too.
Maybe this battle will help put things in order for me.
@BATTLE
Captain, have you heard the phrase "die with your boots on?" I just heard one of the sailors use it, and he rushed off before I could ask him.
An Americanism, I believe. It means dying in action before wasting away in old age.
Going down fighting all the way to the end! Still, many warriors have passed away peacefully.
I can't quite decide how I feel about that.

Fields.MenuText: I can certainly see the appeal of dying in bed. Life is short. Might as well enjoy every scrap you can get of it.
Just dying in some sort of action for it's own sake seems wasteful to me. If you have to die it should be for something.
Dying with valor in battle is ideal for a warrior, but I'm not in a hurry to fulfill it.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. I suppose if you fight your hardest and still survive what lays others low, you've earned that rest. Just got to have something worth fighting for.
Indeed. It's just a matter of finding what that something is.
If you have something worth fighting for, you'll fight like hell to return to it. Or make sure your companions can.
Sorry, Captain, I've been asking you so many strange questions.
Not to worry, Achilles. Compared to a lot of Belles your questions are quite grounded. I always have time for you.
I appreciate that. I am... finding myself on foreign ground. Perhaps... no, more on that later. I always understand the battlefield.
@BATTLE
Captain! I heard something interesting, and it got me thinking about our talk.
Oh? What is it? I'm all ears.
Apparently some of the American sailors were invited to a meeting with a big-deal American officer last time we were in port.
The sailor said something to his friend about dying for one's country. How it's the wrong goal for a soldier or sailor or Marine.
Your aim should be to make the other poor bastard die for their country. Ha!
I can see why you'd enjoy rhetoric like that. So now what do you think about dying in battle? Did you change your mind about it?
I prefer things simple and straightforward, but maybe it's not always as easy as that. This bears investigating.

Fields.MenuText: You need to settle on what you're investigating first.
Are you really doing all this to avoid admitting you have an arrogant streak at times?
What's going on with all this?

Fields.DialogueText: I have an idea! I just... can't express it yet.
No! Of course not. That's preposterous, Captain.
I'll tell you, Captain, soon. I promise. Just... bear with me as you have been.
Really, it will all be made clear soon! I promise. Now, I'm sensing Morganas on the prowl!
Is she hiding something from me?
@BATTLE
Achilles, take a seat.
Oh, Captain, I was just passing by and...
Take a seat.
You're looking... quite serious today, Captain. If I'm candid, it's a good look for you.
I'm sick of waiting for you to explain yourself. Out with it. What's all this been about?
I... took the Belle's words to heart in the end, and thought I'd reassess my own values and beliefs. Especially in terms of what and who I am.
A responsible, mature response to being challenged. I'm impressed.
Then I'll get in her face and challenge her ideals in turn.
... and that's more like the Achilles I know.

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't it be more efficient to just resolve the question for yourself and get on with the war?
Do you really have nothing better to do with your time?
Considering you got into a shooting match with your own conventional sister once, I suppose having a proper Belle opponent would get you fired up even more.

Fields.DialogueText: Leave a battle unfought when victory beckons? For shame!
Not that I can think of. What could be more important than defending your own virtue?
What's wrong with that? Ajax started it, I'll have you recall!
Anyway, Captain, I think I'm making progress on all this... I...
*ALARM*
Hold that thought.
Sure. Later. Right.
@BATTLE
Ah, Achilles, there... are you... giggling?
Captain! Where did you come from? No! Of course not! Not giggling or anything.
What are you hiding behind your back there? And why is it chirping?
I... don't have anything! At all! Certainly nothing chirping! Could be you've gotten a bit too much sun, Captain.
Yup... let me just peek here... That's a cute little bird. Where did you find that?
Oh! There's a bird there. Huh, how did that happen?

Fields.MenuText: It's nuzzling your hand.
I suppose it would have something to do with that birdseed.
Are you expanding your collection of messenger pigeons?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah... I wonder why it's doing that.
Birdseed? What birdseed? Oh! That birdseed. I wonder where that came from.
I have no idea what you're talking about, Captain!
I... uh... I have to go, Captain!Morganas!
Achilles, wait, your birdseed! Damn, she's gone.
That was a colorful little bird, too. It's not often I catch Achilles acting cute.
@BATTLE
Come on! Move those shells! Faster! We're heading into combat, not going on a pleasure cruise!
There you are, Achilles. I need you on the bridge. What are you doing down here?
Ensuring that everything is in place for my victory, of course.
I'll be damned if I let these Morganas deface my ocean a moment longer!
Fine, fine, let's just get to the bridge.
XO, status?
Captain, the enemy ships we've located are withdrawing at speed. The fleet reports all ships at action stations, standing by for orders.
Hmm. Something's going on here...
I think that's patently obvious, Captain. They're fleeing like the cowardly filth they are before our might. We should pursue and crush them at once.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think that might leave our area of responsibility open to attack?
And if they're drawing us into an a trap?
Damn right! Helm, flank speed.

Fields.DialogueText: It's always possible... but if we crush the threat, what will they attack with?
Then we crush their pathetic excuse for a trap too!
That's my captain! Come! Battle calls for the brave!
Fleet's coming up to speed. We'll be in range range in ten minutes.
By spear and sword we shall defeat them! Courage!
@BATTLE
Hah! I bet they thought they had us with that second wave!
If that was a trap, it was a particularly weak one. I still can't help but feel like we're missing something...
Captain! Captain! Distress call from south of here! Heavy Morgana attack.
The sector we were patrolling... it was a trap all right, but we weren't the target.
Damn them!
XO, bring the fleet back around. Let's catch the raiders on their way out. Achilles. Get over here. Now.

Fields.MenuText: We messed up. Badly.
Damn, Achilles. We got outplayed.
Seems the enemy's learned to anticipate us.

Fields.DialogueText: Damn... damn them. I won't stand for this!
I can't believe this! I won't!
How? Am I really so... impulsive... that they can bait me like a bull?
Damn it all, why can't they die and stay dead when we slay them! They snatch two victories from our mouths!
None of that matters if we lose the war!
You're... right. This. I'm responsible for this. Captain, the order was yours, but you followed my counsel.
Please excuse me. I need to take a moment alone to... consider this.
I'll have the reports sent to your quarters as they come in. I still need you and your fire, Achilles. Don't let this dampen you.
I'll... try not to, sir.
This could be a very serious problem.
@BATTLE
XO, where's the lady of the house?
I believe she's below in her quarters. She asked not to be disturbed.
Well, I'll just have to brave her wrath.
*CLANK*
GRAH!
Terribly frightening. If that spear target wasn't made of wood, I'm sure it would have died of fright.
I asked not to be disturbed... and you are not helping right now, Captain.
Oh, but I am helping. You're not just training, not just taking a quiet moment alone. You don't fail often.
Am I wrong to suspect that you're down here skulking and self-flagellating instead of making sure it doesn't happen again?
You're... you're wrong. Gah. Damn you to Tartarus, why did I pick a Captain who could see through me so well?
I wouldn't be a decent friend to you, or a decent captain, if I couldn't see through you this well. At the very least I would clearly not know my ship well enough.
Fine... fine. Provide me your enlightened counsel then, my dearest Captain. What would you have of me?
Was that sarcasm? Achilles, I'm so proud of you!
Yes, yes, I'm the ultimate adaptive predator, Nubian would be proud, et cetera. Your point?

Fields.MenuText: You need to get up with the crew and show your best face. You think you're the only one who feels like they've failed right now? Lead by example.
You should be poring over the maps with me in the wardroom so we can figure out exactly what happened and make sure it never happens again.
I don't know what you should do in the end, but I know sulking down here isn't it.

Fields.DialogueText: I... hadn't thought about it like that. They must be upset too, with all those people hurt and killed.
Yes, I should be doing something productive with my emotions.
Heh... you seem to know what to say, even when you don't know what needs to be done. I appreciate that in a Captain.
When a pride of lions take a licking, the dominant lion and dominant lioness don't go off into the brush to sulk. They might not have the complexities of mankind, but such behavior...
...would be ruinous to the morale and welfare of the pride, yes. You're right. Come on, let's show the crew our resolve.
@BATTLE
Captain, lions do not make war - correct?
Not to my knowledge. Man is the only animal that truly makes war.
So why does fighting like a lion refer to the prowess of a single combatant?
Because individually lions are pretty damn scary. The phrase has never really made sense to me, though - lions are pack hunters who fight as a team.
Much like soldiers do when it comes down to it. Perhaps we should extol the virtues of lions in proper context. What do you think, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I think the original meaning has more to do with encouraging individual bravery or valor. Courage is a trait implicitly associated with lions after all.
I can agree that working, living, and fighting as a crew, or as a whole fleet, are implicit to our duty.
I think it might get the crew confused if you try and shift the meaning now.

Fields.DialogueText: And well worth promoting.
Yes, even heroes tend to emphasize the valor of the group over their own personal deeds in this age.
Yes, that's... hmm, it's hard to fight cultural meanings that entrenched.
I shall consider other animals. Perhaps I can find a better example of group combatants.
I doubt you'll have to look far. Working together is one of the common successful traits of animals, especially mammals.
*ALARM*
Oh, how convenient! I do my best thinking in battle.
Remind me to buy you some firecrackers next time you need to have a think.
@BATTLE
As long as we're discussing teamwork, I'll trade you some earplugs. I've been having quite a few thinks lately...
Captain! I believe I've found another species with a worthy  group dynamic.
Go on, what are you thinking?
Well, pack hunting or group hunting behavior is not terribly uncommon. Even dolphins move, live and fight in pods.
I think the masters of it, besides humanity, are wolves. The pack live and die by teamwork.
I find them to be far more tight-knit than the average pride of lions.
Reasonable enough. So where are you going with all of this?
I'm not... entirely sure yet, but I think I'm going in the right direction. To... understanding something.

Fields.MenuText: Wait, you don't even know what you're trying to find out?
How do you answer a question if you don't know the question?
Do you remember why you're pursuing this line of inquiry in the first place, perchance?

Fields.DialogueText: I just... I have a feeling. That's all.
I'll let you know after I find the answer.
Not really, but I know it's important!
I really don't understand you sometimes.
I was making a joke. Somewhat.
Ah. Right, so that's why I was confused.
Ahem... I think there's a moral lesson to be learned for me. I just... need to take some time and process it.
Like... being a proper team player?
Yes... that. Even my namesake could not truly fight alone, and my mindset has gotten people killed. I need to learn how to fight like a wolf.
Well, let me know if I can help in any way.
I will... and you already have, Captain.
@BATTLE
Stand... stand close at my side during this fight, Captain. Maybe we'll start building our pack here.
Captain, have a drink! I have just finished a fresh batch of ambrosia, and while I might be... adrift in some senses, victory must still be toasted.
You know, a lot of Belles brew their own drinks, now that I think about it.
Nothing beats ambrosia, but it makes sense when you think about it. We're paragons of the cultures we represent. Ambrosia is the nectar of the gods.
Certain kinds of wine, beer or liquor are central to many cultures, but they can be very hard to acquire from the supply chain.
Hmm, this tastes pretty good. Very... sweet might be the wrong word. I'm not sure. I like it, though. I swear you've had me try it before.
I know you have. Petty Officer Brodén, one of our Swedish volunteers, tried some and said it reminded him of a beverage called mead.
I asked him to tell me more about it, but the call to battle came before he could. Do you know anything about it, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I'm quite the fan of it. A fermented honey beverage in its base form, like a wine. It's even better with berries added - like juniper berries.
Isn't that the honey wine the Vikings allegedly drank?
I haven't the foggiest, but I'd be willing to give it a try.

Fields.DialogueText: We must acquire or make some at once!
If it was good enough for such warriors, it's certainly worthy of drinking!
A good attitude indeed, Captain!
So many interesting traditions and ways of creating things. This is why I appreciate travel, you know. My body is English, but my heart is Greek.
Plus, travel inevitably leads to new foes to conquer in this day and age!
Well, at least you're enthusiastic, my dear Achilles.
Just you wait, Captain. Once I have my head on straight, I shall be even more enthusiastic still!
A terrifying prospect, but I'll look forward to it. Until then, pass the bottle.
@BATTLE
Oh! Put a cork in it.
Don't be rude.
No, I mean put the cork back in the bottle. We've got Morganas coming!
Good Captain, set your papers aside! We must eat!
Just because you're hungry doesn't mean I... Hey, that smells good.
Fresh-baked bread, wine, and a selection of cheese, meats and vegetables. A proper Greek meal!
I thought about making a traditional British meal... but that is one place I am less grateful for my heritage. Truly, must they boil everything!?

Fields.MenuText: What do you expect from a nation that conquered most of the world trying to find better food?
Boiling works great. You know it's done once the flavor's gone.
I'll have you know it's not all boiled. Some of it's deep-fried.

Fields.DialogueText: A fair point indeed, Captain. You'd think we'd have learned.
Surely you jest!
I can't imagine that's good for the balance of one's humours.
Now, take the bread. To eat traditionally, the bread is your spoon. You can dip it into the soup, or straight into the wine - which is a favorite of mine.
Bread soaked in wine? Interesting. Sounds nice, though.
Try it, try it, try it!
Hmm! Yeah, I could...
*ALARM*
Damn.
Let's see to this quickly, Captain! If we're fast, we can get back before our food goes cold.
@BATTLE
Captain, our gun drill in that last battle was unacceptable.
We weren't loading nearly fast as we could have. I think we were slacking in many places.
Back to basics, for myself and the whole crew. My mistakes have taught me that we need to train and fight as one.
I crave glory and victory, but like a meal tastes best shared, victory is best found with your comrades.
Very insightful, Achilles.
Your thoughts on how best to improve as a unified crew, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Drill, drill, and drill again.
We need physical training. Improve the body, improve the mind.
I'm sure you already have an excellent plan, so I won't steal your thunder.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, a cornerstone of any training is establishing muscle memory.
A crew is only as strong as its weakest link, that's true.
I do indeed, Captain. You know me well.
I'll get the XO and my training plans. Among the three of us, I'm sure we can devise a plan to make us all stronger.
A lone hero just isn't enough, Captain. We all have our weak spots... and if you make a joke about my heel I won't forgive you.
You can't possibly be mad when you set me up like that! Besides, your heel isn't your best feature.
@BATTLE
What is my best feature, then?
*ALARM*
Hmm... Can't decide. So your endless patience will have to be your second best.
I... Oh, my... Wait, come back here! My question stands!
Captain, do you consider mottos important to a group identity?
In a military context? Well...

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely critical to a group identity and building a sense of pride. A rallying cry!
They can have a major impact on a crew.
I think that sort of thing is more garnish for the real meat and potatoes of motivating a crew.

Fields.DialogueText: I can see it that way.
That tells me so little. What do they do?
You make a good point. All the slogans in the world won't rally an incompetent, undisciplined crew.
Got any favorites?
Besides your own: "Fortiter in Re"?
I'm flattered! "Unyielding in Action" suits me - and the men and women who would serve alongside me.
"Gloria Fortis Miles" is a good one, too. The glory of the brave soldier.
I rather like that.
It has a second part, though. "Pervenientes usque ad mortem." Added to the first part, it means "The glory of a brave soldier... arriving unto death."
A bit morbid. I always thought some unit might adopt "Qui audet vincit."
Give it time. A French unit adopted it's founder's family motto, "Le Loup Desire, Le Loup Obtient." What the Wolf Wants, The Wolf Gets.
Amusing! I... wait, blast it all.
I was wondering when that would happen.
This is a distraction. I love spending time with you, but it's back to work.
I always have time for you, you know. Even side tracks all lead round to the destination eventually.
@BATTLE
I feel another side track coming our way...
Morganas?
Morganas.
What the hell is all this stuff on my desk?
Sorry, Captain! I'm bringing the last of it now!
Have you declared war on trees now?
Captain! Please take this seriously. This is the plan I've worked out for the individual training and evaluation of sailors.
Please, please tell me there's a summary in this mess somewhere. Or walk me through it.
I've tied everything back into the promotion system, plus various recommendations for good conduct awards or smaller benefits...
Overnight leave chits when we're in port under appropriate conditions... extra rations of grog...

Fields.MenuText: So it's an incentive system?
So it's integrated from the top down, eh? Interesting.
So what's all the rest of this?

Fields.DialogueText: Precisely.
Building in incentives provides carrots to go with the stick, Captain.
The actual training regimen.
Now I'll walk you through the rest of the program... Oh! I should get us some coffee. This might take awhile.
*ALARM*
Some adrenaline might be all we need.
@BATTLE
That... looks like a different stack of papers from last time.
Perceptive indeed, Captain. Phase two of my plan. Crew training schedule, performance goals, schedules, and appropriate reward recommendations.
I've concluded that such things can be more effective for an already competent crew, rather than applying the lash as if they were weak and lazy.
Good distinction.
As you can see I have a schedule laid out for regular inspections, and drills down to the shift or department level, up to regular training between departments.
Drills are organized by area within the ship and by expertise. Being able to come to each other's aid should continue to foster a culture of communal reliability.
This is very well thought out. I have one question.

Fields.MenuText: Where are you in all of this?
Who is evaluating your progress personally?
None of these rewards really suit you. I think you're taking good care of the crew, but this whole thing started with you. How should I reward your efforts?

Fields.DialogueText: I have to be involved in a fair bit of it as a Belle, but I want to specifically not help in many cases so they can know their skill is their own, not just an artifact of my help.
That would of course be my noble captain! I bend my knee to no other but the Crown and the Gods.
I... hadn't thought of that, actually.
Well, seems we have some holes to cover, but don't worry. I'll help with that. Nice work, Achilles.
A pleasure, Captain. As my evaluation is left to you... I look forward to seeing how you approach it.
We'll implement this training protocol at once...
*ALARM*
Right after we sink these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Strike! Strike! Reset! Strike! Strike! Good! Back up! Nicely done. You're dismissed.
What's going on out here?
Bayonet training! The ground forces use it for inspiring aggression in their soldiers, so I figured we could too.
I've also had them doing some wrestling, boxing, and other forms of sparring, plus group exercises like pulling an anchor up by hand.
That last one seems a tad dangerous.
I have safety precautions in place, including stops and bars to grip to keep everyone's fingers attached.
There's been some grumbling, but I think it's going very well, Captain! I'll have a crew of warriors for you in no time at all!

Fields.MenuText: Remind me again how this is making them better sailors?
Keep this up and the other armed services might start poaching our crew!
Should I be worried about my training program?

Fields.DialogueText: Boosting individual physical condition and fighting spirit improves the whole!
Hah, I'll accept that as quite the compliment should it happen. But they are mine first.
Not per se. Our training sessions will be one on one... just you and me, Captain.
Now! Come with me, Captain. It's time for your first training session. I hope you remember some basic hand to hand.
If not, don't worry. I'll get you up to snuff.
I'd say go easy on me, but that wouldn't do anything except make you go even harder, wouldn't it?
You have to be an example for the crew, after all! That means being better than the average sailor, and then some.
Fine, fine. Let me change into something appropriate for getting thrown around a room.
@BATTLE
After we clean up these witches, Captain! I'll make sure they leave enough of you for me.
For you?
... To whip into shape! Of course.
Captain! Lady Achilles! Enemy ships on the horizon!
Our first catch of the day, Captain.
Indeed. Hmm... I wonder.
Wonder what?
Well, they've lured us out before because they know your behavior. Stay out in front. Let's keep up appearances. I've got a plan.
What plan is this, Captain?
I'll tell you later when it's done... but it's nothing we can use yet. Anything you want to say to the crew before we hop to it?
Ahem... Crew of the HMS Achilles! As we sail into these coming conflicts, sharpened and reforged by hard training, you must know that...
... I am proud of all of you! We have before us the opportunity to be heroes. My namesake is a man who became a legend.
The heroes made in this war today can become tomorrow's legends. Let's forge our legend together!

Fields.MenuText: This is the captain. I will only add that I expect your names to shine.
You heard the Lady! Let's show the foe who we are.
Fortiter in Re!

Fields.DialogueText: And so do I.
Then carve our names into their hulls so they don't forget.
Fortiter in Re!
All hands to action stations.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Anything to add, Captain?
It wouldn't have been complete without you, Captain. Thank you.
Wolf pack, remember? I've got my part to play. I'll play it to the hilt.
Indeed. That too.
Come on! Move those shells! We don't even have the luxury of sweating in peace any more! Sweat or bleed! You pick!
Firing!
*BOOM*
Hit!
Right! Secure the guns... time... good. New record! Double ration of grog for the gun crews tonight.
Aye-aye, sir!
Heh. I am quite pleased with this, Captain. I think it's all starting to fall into place.
To that end, I have a plan. We've been talking about my issues, and the enemy has even used them against us. I want to strike back, using my past... shortcomings.
Well, go on, don't keep me in suspense.
The enemy expects to be able to "lead" me a bit, because I tend to charge like an enraged bull. What if we take steps to appear that way and use that to trap them?

Fields.MenuText: So more or less make some sort of pincer movement?
How would you envision that working?
I can see the potential there. Tell me all about it and we'll write it up for command.

Fields.DialogueText: Not quite. More like divide and conquer. Ambush the ambushers.
I have the plan all laid out based on their last attempt to bait me.
Of course, Captain.
In short, I get in front of the fleet, leaving them looking disorganized. Meanwhile, our actual defensive fleet is lying in wait.
That force will intercept the second Morgana force that will likely come in after we're "out of position."
Interesting... we need to be able to get the enemy to pull that plan again.
If I sell that my behaviour hasn't changed, they won't feel the need to adapt.
And when the time is right, we drop the hammer. Get your charts, and let's get this written up. Nice work, Achilles.
@BATTLE
We can put it to paper once we clear the seas. I think our drills attracted some shades!
Captain! Targets sighted.
Exactly where we predicted they'd turn up! Intelligence is getting good at playing this guessing game. Captain, your orders?

Fields.MenuText: Right, just like we planned.
You know what to do. Make it happen.
All ahead full. Get the fleet moving.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye!
My pride shall be their downfall!
I lead by example as always.
Confirm with the other ships. Appear disorganized, and keep their speed down till we're properly out front.
Fleet is moving as planned, Captain!
Good, let's make a good show of it for our audience. Get us in knife-fighting range! Gunnery Officer, open fire when you've got targets.
Aye, sir.
Sail me closer! I want to hit them with my spear!
Acting like your usual bullheaded battle rush. Acting. Not actually losing control, right?
Nothing stopping me from having fun while we do it! Especially with all these lovely targets presenting themselves for us.
Is it my birthday? Did the Morganas bring me a present?
I really can't tell if you're teasing me or getting into character.
A bit of both.
I suppose I asked for that.
@BATTLE
And you wouldn't have it any other way.
Everything is in position, Captain. Aerial recon confirms exactly what we thought. Multiple Morgana forces out there: baits, ambushers, and raiders.
Are all our surprises in place?
The guests are seated, the food is coming out of the kitchen, and the drinks are being poured. Now all this party needs is some music and, of course, our host. You.
Ah, but it wouldn't be a party without my lovely hostess on my arm.
Flatterer... but I'll allow it! You may praise me at will, Captain.
Keep preening like that, and your birds will think you're one of them.

Fields.MenuText: The stage is set. The players are assembled. Let's begin.
Sound general quarters. All hands to action stations.
Lets get a final tactical overview and get to work.

Fields.DialogueText: Now you're just being overly dramatic.
I'm going to slay them like my namesake butchered Hector. We might be a trick... but we can still take our price in blood!
Hah! Do you want to live forever? Come! The battle cry beckons!
We have reforged ourselves! Let us now be tested, the only way a worthy warrior can be!
Range?
About to make gun range, sir!
Fire!
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
Orders, Captain?
Last enemy ships immobilized, Captain!
Hah! They did not enjoy the taste of our steel one bit.
They never saw our counter coming. They won't fool again nearly as easily.
Not with the same trick... but like Odysseus, we must be cunning as well as bold.

Fields.MenuText: Status of the fleet?
Excellent work! First round of drinks is on me when we make port.
How did the other ships do?

Fields.DialogueText: Always the professional, Captain.
Hah! I'll break out a special cask of ambrosia for this!
I'm sure they did fine, Captain. Fret not!
Reports from the other fleets is that they turned and destroyed the enemy raiding force. No damage to civilian ships or structures, Lady Achilles.
Whatever those sea witches want, they shan't have it. Not this day, nor the next!
Do a final sweep of the immediate area, then secure from general quarters. I'll expect the fleet's damage and casualty reports in my ready in ten minutes.
@BATTLE
If any other Morganas are out here, we'll find them.
Captain, I brought a small cask of ambrosia to share. I notice you didn't join the crew for the festivities.
You know how it is. No one likes the boss around when they're trying to relax.
For a normal captain, perhaps. For a Belle Captain?
Belle or no Belle, a captain is bound to his ship like a spouse.
Lucky for me, when I talk to my ship, she speaks back.
What about you? This is your big moment, and I thought you'd be in the thick of things below deck.
I... felt as though I might be causing disquiet as well, and... well I missed your company. I've also been reflecting a bit.

Fields.MenuText: You? Reflecting on something? Should I call for the chief engineer?
What's on your mind Achilles?

Fields.DialogueText: Always the comedian, Captain.
Well, it's just... a feeling.
Roman generals on parade in the streets of Rome had a man by their side whispering in their ear, "Remember you are mortal." Right?
My mind drifted to another motto, related to our previous talk on the subject. Sic Transit Gloria Mundi.
"Thus passes worldly glory"? That's not really a motto, is it?
Not a motto for our ship, no. Just a thought that made me sad. I don't want this time to end.
We accomplished great things, and maybe people will remember what we did... but what matters to me the most is the time right now.
My time with you.
Do you really? Do you hear every cry and explosion whispering in your ear, telling you you are mortal?
You have to be the most sentimental warrior I've ever known.
Maybe the best ones are. Maybe I'm looking at one right now.
Takes one to know one.
Takes one to kiss one.
I understand...
Just like Thermopylae, remember? Leonidas and his men didn't need anyone whispering to them. They saw it and felt it in their struggle.

Fields.MenuText: Are you all right?

Fields.DialogueText: More than you know, Captain. Just... contemplative. I've rarely had cause before.
And fought all the harder for it.
As we... As our people have grown closer, so have they grown louder.
I yield.
As do I. Let's call this one a draw.
